an7.42:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
an7.42:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

an7.42:1.3.eng: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.

an7.42:1.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
an7.42:1.4.eng: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

an7.42:1.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodi.
an7.42:1.5.eng: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

an7.42:1.6.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an7.42:1.6.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

an7.42:1.7.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
an7.42:1.7.eng: Now at that time while those wanderers of other religions were sitting together this discussion came up among them,

an7.42:1.8.pli: “yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
an7.42:1.8.eng: “Reverends, anyone who lives the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’.”

an7.42:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandi nappaṭikkosi.
an7.42:2.1.eng: Sāriputta neither approved nor rejected that statement of the wanderers of other religions.

an7.42:2.2.eng: He got up from his seat, thinking,

an7.42:2.3.eng: “I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

an7.42:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.42:2.4.eng: Then Sāriputta wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding:

an7.42:3.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.

an7.42:3.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan’ti.

an7.42:3.5.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhante, yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.

an7.42:3.6.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ.

an7.42:3.7.pli: Tena kho pana, bhante, samayena tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:

an7.42:3.8.pli: ‘yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, niddaso bhikkhūti alaṃvacanāyā’ti.

an7.42:3.9.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.

an7.42:3.12.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetun”ti?
an7.42:3.12.eng: “Sir, in this teaching and training can we describe a mendicant as a ‘graduate’ solely because they have completed a certain number of years?”

an7.42:4.1.pli: “Na kho, sāriputta, sakkā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetuṃ.

an7.42:4.2.pli: Satta kho imāni, sāriputta, niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an7.42:4.2.eng: I make known these seven qualifications for graduation after realizing them with my own insight.

an7.42:5.2.pli: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo, dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo, icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo, paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo, vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo, satinepakke tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo, diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
an7.42:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training … to examine the teachings … to get rid of desires … for retreat … to rouse up energy … for mindfulness and alertness … to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.

an7.42:5.3.pli: Imāni kho, sāriputta, satta niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an7.42:5.3.eng: These are the seven qualifications for graduation that I make known after realizing them with my own insight.

an7.42:5.4.pli: Imehi kho, sāriputta, sattahi niddasavatthūhi samannāgato bhikkhu dvādasa cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;
an7.42:5.4.eng: A mendicant who has these seven qualifications for graduation is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’. This is so whether they have lived the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years,

an7.42:5.5.pli: catubbīsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;

an7.42:5.6.pli: chattiṃsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya, aṭṭhacattārīsañcepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.

an7.43:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an7.43:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an7.43:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
an7.43:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.

an7.43:1.5.eng: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Kosambī.

an7.43:1.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
an7.43:1.6.eng: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”

an7.43:1.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodi.
an7.43:1.7.eng: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

an7.43:1.8.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an7.43:1.8.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

an7.43:2.1.eng: Now at that time while those wanderers of other religions were sitting together this discussion came up among them,

an7.43:2.2.pli: “yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
an7.43:2.2.eng: “Reverends, anyone who lives the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’.”

an7.43:3.2.eng: He got up from his seat, thinking,

an7.43:3.3.eng: “I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

an7.43:3.4.eng: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Kosambī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding:

an7.43:4.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan’ti …pe…

an7.43:4.6.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ.

an7.43:5.2.pli: ‘yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, niddaso bhikkhūti alaṃvacanāyā’ti.

an7.43:5.6.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetun”ti?
an7.43:5.6.eng: “Sir, in this teaching and training can we describe a mendicant as a ‘graduate’ solely because they have completed a certain number of years?”

an7.43:6.1.pli: “Na kho, ānanda, sakkā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetuṃ.

an7.43:6.2.pli: Satta kho imāni, ānanda, niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an7.43:6.2.eng: These are the seven qualifications for graduation that I make known after realizing them with my own insight.

an7.43:7.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu, saddho hoti, hirīmā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, satimā hoti, paññavā hoti.
an7.43:7.2.eng: It’s when someone is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

an7.43:7.3.pli: Imāni kho, ānanda, satta niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an7.43:7.3.eng: These are the seven qualifications for graduation that I make known after realizing them with my own insight.

an7.43:7.4.pli: Imehi kho, ānanda, sattahi niddasavatthūhi samannāgato bhikkhu dvādasa cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;
an7.43:7.4.eng: A mendicant who possesses these seven qualifications for graduation is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’. This is so whether they have lived the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years,

an7.43:7.5.pli: catubbīsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;

an7.43:7.6.pli: chattiṃsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya, aṭṭhacattārīsañcepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.

an7.44:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven planes of consciousness.

an7.44:1.3.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā, ekacce ca devā, ekacce ca vinipātikā.
an7.44:1.3.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.

an7.44:1.4.eng: This is the first plane of consciousness.

an7.44:2.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
an7.44:2.1.eng: There are sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception, such as the gods reborn in the Divinity’s host through the first absorption.

an7.44:2.2.eng: This is the second plane of consciousness.

an7.44:3.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
an7.44:3.1.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception, such as the gods of streaming radiance.

an7.44:3.2.eng: This is the third plane of consciousness.

an7.44:4.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
an7.44:4.1.eng: There are sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception, such as the gods of universal beauty.

an7.44:4.2.eng: This is the fourth plane of consciousness.

an7.44:5.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
an7.44:5.1.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form. With the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite space.

an7.44:5.2.eng: This is the fifth plane of consciousness.

an7.44:6.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
an7.44:6.1.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space. Aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they have been reborn in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an7.44:6.2.eng: This is the sixth plane of consciousness.

an7.44:7.1.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
an7.44:7.1.eng: There are sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness. Aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they have been reborn in the dimension of nothingness.

an7.44:7.2.eng: This is the seventh plane of consciousness.

an7.44:8.1.eng: These are the seven planes of consciousness.”

an7.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven prerequisites for immersion.

an7.45:1.3.pli: Sammādiṭṭhi, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvācā, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati.
an7.45:1.3.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness.

an7.45:1.4.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, imehi sattahaṅgehi cittassekaggatā parikkhatā, ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso itipi saparikkhāro itipī”ti.
an7.45:1.4.eng: Unification of mind with these seven factors as prerequisites is what is called noble right immersion ‘with its vital conditions’ and also ‘with its prerequisites’.”

an7.46:1.3.pli: Rāgaggi, dosaggi, mohaggi, āhuneyyaggi, gahapataggi, dakkhiṇeyyaggi, kaṭṭhaggi—
an7.46:1.3.eng: The fires of greed, hate, delusion. The fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods. A householder’s fire. The fire of those worthy of a religious donation. And a wood fire.

an7.47:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena uggatasarīrassa brāhmaṇassa mahāyañño upakkhaṭo hoti.
an7.47:1.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Uggatasarīra had prepared a large sacrifice.

an7.47:1.2.pli: Pañca usabhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca vacchatarasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca vacchatarisatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca ajasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya, pañca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya.
an7.47:1.2.eng: Bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats and rams—five hundred of each—had been led to the post for the sacrifice.

an7.47:1.3.pli: Atha kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an7.47:1.3.eng: Then the brahmin Uggatasarīra went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an7.47:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.47:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

an7.47:2.1.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.
an7.47:2.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard that kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post is very fruitful and beneficial.”

an7.47:2.2.pli: “Mayāpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.

an7.47:2.4.pli: tatiyampi kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.47:2.4.eng: and third time Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha,

an7.47:2.5.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.
an7.47:2.5.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard that kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post is very fruitful and beneficial.”

an7.47:2.6.pli: “Mayāpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, sutaṃ aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan”ti.

an7.47:2.7.pli: “Tayidaṃ, bho gotama, sameti bhoto ceva gotamassa amhākañca, yadidaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ”.
an7.47:2.7.eng: “Then the worthy Gotama and I are in total agreement in this matter.”

an7.47:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte āyasmā ānando uggatasarīraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
an7.47:3.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to Uggatasarīra,

an7.47:3.2.eng: “Brahmin, you shouldn’t ask the Buddha in this way.

an7.47:3.3.pli: ‘sutaṃ metaṃ, bho gotama, aggissa ādānaṃ yūpassa ussāpanaṃ mahapphalaṃ hoti mahānisaṃsan’ti.

an7.47:3.4.eng: You should ask in this way:

an7.47:3.5.eng: ‘Sir, I want to kindle the sacrificial fire and raise the sacrificial post.

an7.47:3.7.pli: Anusāsatu maṃ, bhante, bhagavā yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā’”ti.
an7.47:3.7.eng: and instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’”

an7.47:4.1.pli: Atha kho uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.47:4.1.eng: Then Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha,

an7.47:4.2.pli: “ahañhi, bho gotama, aggiṃ ādātukāmo yūpaṃ ussāpetukāmo.
an7.47:4.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I want to kindle the sacrificial fire and raise the sacrificial post.

an7.47:4.3.eng: May the worthy Gotama please advise

an7.47:4.4.pli: Anusāsatu maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an7.47:4.4.eng: and instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”

an7.47:5.1.pli: “Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā tīṇi satthāni ussāpeti akusalāni dukkhudrayāni dukkhavipākāni.
an7.47:5.1.eng: “Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post, one raises three unskillful knives which ripen and result in suffering.

an7.47:5.3.eng: The knives of the body, speech, and mind.

an7.47:5.4.pli: Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā evaṃ cittaṃ uppādesi:
an7.47:5.4.eng: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one gives rise to the thought:

an7.47:5.5.pli: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāyā’ti.
an7.47:5.5.eng: ‘May this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice!’

an7.47:5.6.pli: So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati.
an7.47:5.6.eng: Thinking, ‘May I make goodness’, one makes wickedness. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.

an7.47:5.7.pli: Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ paṭhamaṃ manosatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ.
an7.47:5.7.eng: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises this first unskillful mental knife which ripens and results in suffering.

an7.47:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, aggiṃ ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati:
an7.47:6.1.eng: Furthermore, even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post, one says such things as:

an7.47:6.2.pli: ‘ettakā usabhā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatarā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā vacchatariyo haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā ajā haññantu yaññatthāya, ettakā urabbhā haññantu yaññatthāyā’ti.
an7.47:6.2.eng: ‘May this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice!’

an7.47:6.3.pli: So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati.
an7.47:6.3.eng: Thinking, ‘May I make goodness’, one makes wickedness. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.

an7.47:6.4.pli: Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ dutiyaṃ vacīsatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ.
an7.47:6.4.eng: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises this second unskillful verbal knife which ripens and results in suffering.

an7.47:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, aggiṃ ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati usabhā hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati vacchatarā hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati vacchatariyo hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati ajā hantuṃ yaññatthāya, sayaṃ paṭhamaṃ samārambhati urabbhā hantuṃ yaññatthāya.
an7.47:7.1.eng: Furthermore, even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one first personally undertakes preparations for the sacrificial slaughter of bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams.

an7.47:7.2.pli: So ‘puññaṃ karomī’ti apuññaṃ karoti, ‘kusalaṃ karomī’ti akusalaṃ karoti, ‘sugatiyā maggaṃ pariyesāmī’ti duggatiyā maggaṃ pariyesati.
an7.47:7.2.eng: Thinking, ‘May I make goodness’, one makes wickedness. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.

an7.47:7.3.pli: Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā idaṃ tatiyaṃ kāyasatthaṃ ussāpeti akusalaṃ dukkhudrayaṃ dukkhavipākaṃ.
an7.47:7.3.eng: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post, one raises this third unskillful bodily knife which ripens and results in suffering.

an7.47:7.4.pli: Aggiṃ, brāhmaṇa, ādento yūpaṃ ussāpento pubbeva yaññā imāni tīṇi satthāni ussāpeti akusalāni dukkhudrayāni dukkhavipākāni.
an7.47:7.4.eng: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post, one raises these three unskillful knives which ripen and result in suffering.

an7.47:8.1.pli: Tayome, brāhmaṇa, aggī pahātabbā parivajjetabbā, na sevitabbā.
an7.47:8.1.eng: Brahmin, these three fires should be given up and shunned, not cultivated.

an7.47:8.3.eng: The fires of greed, hate, and delusion.

an7.47:9.1.pli: Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, rāgaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo?
an7.47:9.1.eng: And why should the fire of greed be given up and shunned, not cultivated?

an7.47:9.2.pli: Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an7.47:9.2.eng: A greedy person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an7.47:9.3.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an7.47:9.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an7.47:9.4.pli: Tasmāyaṃ rāgaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo.
an7.47:9.4.eng: That’s why the fire of greed should be given up and shunned, not cultivated.

an7.47:10.1.pli: Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, dosaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo?
an7.47:10.1.eng: And why should the fire of hate be given up and shunned, not cultivated?

an7.47:10.2.pli: Duṭṭho kho, brāhmaṇa, dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an7.47:10.2.eng: A hateful person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an7.47:10.3.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an7.47:10.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an7.47:10.4.pli: Tasmāyaṃ dosaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo.
an7.47:10.4.eng: That’s why the fire of hate should be given up and shunned, not cultivated.

an7.47:11.1.pli: Kasmā cāyaṃ, brāhmaṇa, mohaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo?
an7.47:11.1.eng: And why should the fire of delusion be given up and shunned, not cultivated?

an7.47:11.2.pli: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an7.47:11.2.eng: A deluded person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an7.47:11.3.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an7.47:11.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an7.47:11.4.pli: Tasmāyaṃ mohaggi pahātabbo parivajjetabbo, na sevitabbo.
an7.47:11.4.eng: That’s why the fire of delusion should be given up and shunned, not cultivated.

an7.47:11.5.pli: Ime kho tayo, brāhmaṇa, aggī pahātabbā parivajjetabbā, na sevitabbā.
an7.47:11.5.eng: These three fires should be given up and shunned, not cultivated.

an7.47:12.1.pli: Tayo kho, brāhmaṇa, aggī sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbā.
an7.47:12.1.eng: Brahmin, you should properly and happily take care of three fires, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating them.

an7.47:12.3.eng: The fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods. The fire of a householder. And the fire of those worthy of a religious donation.

an7.47:13.1.eng: And what is the fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods?

an7.47:13.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, yassa te honti mātāti vā pitāti vā, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, āhuneyyaggi.
an7.47:13.2.eng: Your mother and father are called the fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.

an7.47:13.4.pli: Atohayaṃ, brāhmaṇa, āhuto sambhūto, tasmāyaṃ āhuneyyaggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo.
an7.47:13.4.eng: Since it is from them that you’ve been incubated and produced. So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.

an7.47:14.1.eng: And what is the fire of a householder?

an7.47:14.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, yassa te honti puttāti vā dārāti vā dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, gahapataggi.
an7.47:14.2.eng: Your children, partners, bondservants, servants, and workers are called a householder’s fire.

an7.47:14.3.pli: Tasmāyaṃ gahapataggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo.
an7.47:14.3.eng: So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.

an7.47:15.1.eng: And what is the fire of those worthy of a religious donation?

an7.47:15.2.pli: Idha, brāhmaṇa, ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā parappavādā paṭiviratā khantisoracce niviṭṭhā ekamattānaṃ damenti, ekamattānaṃ samenti, ekamattānaṃ parinibbāpenti, ayaṃ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, dakkhiṇeyyaggi.
an7.47:15.2.eng: The ascetics and brahmins who refrain from intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves are called the fire of those worthy of a religious donation.

an7.47:15.3.pli: Tasmāyaṃ dakkhiṇeyyaggi sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbo.
an7.47:15.3.eng: So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.

an7.47:15.4.pli: Ime kho, brāhmaṇa, tayo aggī sakkatvā garuṃ katvā mānetvā pūjetvā sammā sukhaṃ parihātabbā.
an7.47:15.4.eng: You should properly and happily take care of these three fires, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating them.

an7.47:16.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana, brāhmaṇa, kaṭṭhaggi kālena kālaṃ ujjaletabbo, kālena kālaṃ ajjhupekkhitabbo, kālena kālaṃ nibbāpetabbo, kālena kālaṃ nikkhipitabbo”ti.
an7.47:16.1.eng: But the wood fire, brahmin, should, from time to time, be fanned, watched over with equanimity, extinguished, or put aside.”

an7.47:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, uggatasarīro brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.47:17.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha,

an7.47:17.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatanti.
an7.47:17.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

an7.47:17.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bho gotama, pañca usabhasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca vacchatarasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca vacchatarisatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca ajasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi, pañca urabbhasatāni muñcāmi jīvitaṃ demi.
an7.47:17.4.eng: Worthy Gotama, I now set free these five hundred bulls, five hundred bullocks, five hundred heifers, five hundred goats, and five hundred rams. I give them life!

an7.47:17.5.pli: Haritāni ceva tiṇāni khādantu, sītāni ca pānīyāni pivantu, sīto ca nesaṃ vāto upavāyatan”ti.
an7.47:17.5.eng: May they eat grass and drink cool water and enjoy a cool breeze!”

an7.48:1.1.pli: “Sattimā, bhikkhave, saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an7.48:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these seven perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.

an7.48:2.2.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā.
an7.48:2.2.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering.

an7.48:2.3.pli: Imā kho, bhikkhave, satta saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā”ti.
an7.48:2.3.eng: These seven perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. They have freedom from death as their objective and culmination.”
